awd_titl_txt: Workshop on Symmetries in Graphs, Maps, and Polytopes 2022
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports participation of US-based researchers in the 2022 Workshop on Symmetries in Graphs, Maps, and Polytopes (SIGMAP) held at the University of Alaska Fairbanks July 10-16, 2022. Symmetry has motivated many important questions in mathematics, beginning with the study of the Platonic solids in antiquity. Symmetric discrete geometric objects, such as polyhedra or graphs, have a wide variety of applications, from understanding the structure of crystals and the shapes of viruses, to computer-aided modeling and optimization in networks. The workshop will bring together researchers from all over the world to discuss recent advances in the study of symmetries of discrete geometric objects, explore open problems, form new collaborations, and advance existing ones.

The major topic to be addressed at the workshop is the relation of symmetry, both combinatorial and geometric, to the study of graphs, maps, convex and abstract polytopes, and related algebraic and geometric structures. Established researchers in these areas will present recent work to their colleagues, advancing the state of knowledge in the field. The structure of the workshop will facilitate collaborations between current and new researchers in the area through active discussion of open problems and work sessions. Results from the workshop and related research will be disseminated through a special issue of The Art of Discrete and Applied Mathematics focused on Symmetries of Graphs, Maps, and Polytopes. More information about the workshop, including pre-registration forms and opportunities for travel support for US residents, is available at https://www.alaska.edu/sigmap.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Drs. Williams and Berman organized and hosted the 2022 Symmetries in Graphs, Maps and Abstract Polytopes Workshop (SIGMAP) at the University of Alaska Fairbanks July 10-15, 2022. The Symmetries in Graphs, Maps, and Polytopes Workshop provides researchers interested in symmetries of discrete objects and structures opportunities to meet, share results, discuss open problems, and start new collaborations. The first SIGMAP workshop was organized by Stephen Wilson in 1998 in Flagstaff, Arizona, and has been held every four years since then. We were proud to host 28 talks, including 9 plenary speakers, with 43 participants from 12 countries around the world. Time was also set aside during the workshop to provide opportunities for starting new collaborations and continuing existing ones, with a particular eye towards the mentoring of early career mathematicians.

We were also pleased to present a public lecture by Dr. Asia Ivic-Weiss entitled Geometry & Art - A Personal Perspective, which was well attended. A video of the lecture is available on the conference website at https://www.alaska.edu/sigmap.

A special issue of the journal The Art of Discrete and Applied Mathematics containing eight articles prepared by workshop participants is in the late stages of prepartion, with five of the articles already available online. Most of these article were either collaborations that began at the workshop, or were actively worked on during the collaboration sessions.

Conference funds from the NSF were used to support the participation of nine American mathematicians, including four graduate students.
